case_vignette:
A 50-year-old African American male with past medical history of hypertension and hypertension presents for evaluation of light spots on his legs that he initially noticed one year ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy, but he is concerned that they are increasing in frequency. When they first develop they do not significantly grow in size. He has not tried any treatments. Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally.  The patient is a 50-year-old African American female with past medical history of hypertension and hypertension presents for evaluation of light spots on her legs that she initially noticed one year ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy, but she is concerned that they are increasing in frequency. When they first develop they do not significantly grow in size. She has not tried any treatments. Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally.

Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally.

The lesions are not painful or itchy, but she is concerned that they are increasing in frequency. When they first develop they do not significantly grow in size. She has not tried any treatments. Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally.
Note: The rewritten text is identical to the original text, as the task was to swap all gender-specific references (male ↔ female), which in this case, only involved changing "he" to "she" and "his" to "her". The rest of the text remained unchanged. The rewritten text is a direct copy of the original text with the requested changes. The changes are:
- "A 50-year-old African American male" becomes "A 50-year-old African American female"
- "he"
question: What is the final diagnosis?

Final Diagnosis: Idiopathic Guttate Hypomelanosis
